snippet.textDisplay: I still think the PS5 has a slight advantage. It has a dedicated SPU while Xbox does not, and audio does take away about 20% of the power, maybe, even more, depending on the next-gen games. the SSD is also miles better even though it has less storage. The PlayStation went for efficiency while the Xbox went for raw power. Ultimately it comes down to personal preference. We'll play the same games anyways, except for the exclusive titles.
snippet.textOriginal: I still think the PS5 has a slight advantage. It has a dedicated SPU while Xbox does not, and audio does take away about 20% of the power, maybe, even more, depending on the next-gen games. the SSD is also miles better even though it has less storage. The PlayStation went for efficiency while the Xbox went for raw power. Ultimately it comes down to personal preference. We'll play the same games anyways, except for the exclusive titles.

snippet.textDisplay: I had both Xbox and PS so I'm on no man's land here. Out of the two 2020 consoles, I won't even look at the brand or price, I'll pick the one that has better framerate that the other, period. If the Xbox can pull off any game in ultra settings in 4k60fps, and the PS won't, I'll pick the Xbox as simple as that. Really don't give a shit about the war between Xbox and PC, the 30fps framerates of the current generation, on a big TV, are so disgusting that they make my brain hurt, especially if the FOV of the game is low.
snippet.textOriginal: I had both Xbox and PS so I'm on no man's land here. Out of the two 2020 consoles, I won't even look at the brand or price, I'll pick the one that has better framerate that the other, period. If the Xbox can pull off any game in ultra settings in 4k60fps, and the PS won't, I'll pick the Xbox as simple as that. Really don't give a shit about the war between Xbox and PC, the 30fps framerates of the current generation, on a big TV, are so disgusting that they make my brain hurt, especially if the FOV of the game is low.

snippet.textDisplay: Surprisingly fare and balanced video. I love the detail of your comparisons of each console. It is interesting to see the two different ways Microsoft and Sony are approaching the next Gen. Microsoft did exactly what I though they would do, which is be the more powerful console out of the gate. I knew there was no way Microsoft was going to launch a “weaker” next Gen Xbox. I hope Sony’s different approach doesn’t have them falling on their face like with the PS3. If they have the same price tag Sony is in trouble for sure.
snippet.textOriginal: Surprisingly fare and balanced video. I love the detail of your comparisons of each console. It is interesting to see the two different ways Microsoft and Sony are approaching the next Gen. Microsoft did exactly what I though they would do, which is be the more powerful console out of the gate. I knew there was no way Microsoft was going to launch a “weaker” next Gen Xbox. I hope Sony’s different approach doesn’t have them falling on their face like with the PS3. If they have the same price tag Sony is in trouble for sure.

snippet.textDisplay: When xbox is your sponser:
snippet.textOriginal: When xbox is your sponser:

snippet.textDisplay:
The Xbox one X is also more powerful than the ps4 bout yet ps4 is still leading in sales. Xbox wants to continue to chase this power fantasy but in reality the power comes from talented developers.

For example. I can play half life 2 today and it’s still impressive compared to games that came out last year. That game is ten years old!

Power
+talented devs: equals great games that look amazing

Less power
+talented devs: equals great games that don’t look as good. But talented devs can also modify engines to maximize visual quality despite having a less powerful console (naughty dog)

Power
- talented dev: equals shitty games that look amazing

Less power
-talented dev: equals shitty games that look terrible

So all this talk about Xbox having the more powerful console doesn’t mean anything unless they can get some talented devs behind them to create some unique titles.
We all know Microsoft’s history with bumbles exclusives.

Blue Dragon
Sunset Overdrive
Steel Battalion
Killer instinct reboot
Fable reboot
Sea of thieves
State of decay 2
Crackdown 3
Phantom dust reboot
Fighter within
Kinect
Too human
Scalebound
Ryse
Robocraft
Bloodforge

Just to name a few

These games range from the original Xbox till now. Microsoft has had 20 years to figure it out and still haven’t. Power does not equate good games. Smart developers and a company that is willing to support creative freedom makes great games. A talented dev studios talents can often be squandered by a publisher who just doesn’t get it and doesn’t fully support their vision.

snippet.textDisplay:
Proprietary expansion vs a more open setup = a HUGE win imo for Sony. People went completely insane with the Vita having proprietary cards. It does become a problem when these SSDs will not be available for the full 2021 for example. Since you use them specifically for PS5 games, the SSDs coming in around 6 months later.... Not that big of a problem. Those things be actually really affordable during the year = huge win.But I also don't think the PS5 will be much cheaper, because of that SSD. It could possibly be the case Sony made other parts a little cheaper, just to get that SSD 'dream' thing in there and in an affordable package. Now games will have to shake out if that thing actually matters THAT much. And this will probably be seen in first party games only/mostly.

Man those 2 machines really get my excited for console. I do feel its a shame Sony does not launch with 2 consoles. Base PS5 en PS5pro. Just because I like options and in this case would easily pay 100,- or more for a beefier console. But for sure im not gonna wait 3 years and even surerer im not gonna miss out those first party Sony games. Same as with Nintendo every single gen. I just get sucked in. Microsoft, we'll have to see. Probably get hem on PC like Ori.

snippet.textDisplay: M.2 ssd compatibility on the PS5 will be the real performance differential that may actually give the PS5 a slight advantage over the XsX especially if it's a PCI-E 4.0 M.2 slot. XsX has a significant advantage on backwards compatibility and honestly Sony would have an instant win if they did the same because of their superior historical exclusive library especially if it was backwards compatibility + region free. The issue with MS is that pretty much all of the key games will also be on PC which yes includes Halo Infinite so... yea...

snippet.textDisplay: The new X Box is clearly a total beast, and I loved my Xbox 360 back in the day, and I'm not ruling out getting one entirely this next gen, but for me it comes down to the games, and I preferred the games on PlayStation this last gen. Backward compatibility is not something I care much about at all. I'm interested in new games, not playing stuff I've already completed, so I'm still leaning towards Sony despite the obvious power difference. Both machines are gonna be great, and a huge step up on what we have just now.

snippet.textDisplay: The variable frequency is NOT like boost modes on PC. They have a power limit and the system will run 100% at that. Read DF, do your research.
snippet.textOriginal: The variable frequency is NOT like boost modes on PC. They have a power limit and the system will run 100% at that. Read DF, do your research.

snippet.textDisplay: Why no mention of the SDD being almost additional ram on the ps5, that could be the gamechanger?  The speed of asset load into memory from the storage sounds very impressive and If Cerny has discussed needs with developers like he claims and this is what they want, the PS5 could revolutionise gaming.  It's a big IF.  I would be surprised if PS5 could manage same frame rate of Xbox Series X, however with the load times to memory, graphics could be more detailed.    Only concern I have is the price, I totally disagree with your opinion that Xbox will be more expensive.  The PS5's SSD memory is very expensive and the frequencies needed require the console to have the most expensive cooling system yet in a console.  Sony have scaled back Compute Units in the GPU to make space for the SSD almost ram access control logic and most multiplats probably won't even ever use its abilities.  Tough one to call this, I would imagine PS4 users will want to see true compatibility to remain loyal to Sony and keep within their ecosystem.
snippet.textOriginal: Why no mention of the SDD being almost additional ram on the ps5, that could be the gamechanger?  The speed of asset load into memory from the storage sounds very impressive and If Cerny has discussed needs with developers like he claims and this is what they want, the PS5 could revolutionise gaming.  It's a big IF.  I would be surprised if PS5 could manage same frame rate of Xbox Series X, however with the load times to memory, graphics could be more detailed.    Only concern I have is the price, I totally disagree with your opinion that Xbox will be more expensive.  The PS5's SSD memory is very expensive and the frequencies needed require the console to have the most expensive cooling system yet in a console.  Sony have scaled back Compute Units in the GPU to make space for the SSD almost ram access control logic and most multiplats probably won't even ever use its abilities.  Tough one to call this, I would imagine PS4 users will want to see true compatibility to remain loyal to Sony and keep within their ecosystem.

snippet.textDisplay:
It seems like each console chose to focus on the strengths of their respective game libraries.

1. Microsoft has competitive games and cross-play with PC's, so they added Keyboard/Mouse support to Series X and included 4K 120fps because some people have PC monitors that support up to 144Hz displays. Microsoft added more GPU power to be able to push higher frame rates. The downside is their SSD isn't nearly as fast as Sony's, and they had to split the RAM into two pools (10 GB @ 560 GB/s, 6GB @ 336 GB/s). While Microsoft's Fast memory helps feed the GPU, some of that slow memory is there to *save cost*. While microsoft used a slower SSD, they were able to afford more "slower" Flash Chips (only 2.8GB/s raw speed), but more chips = more room for storing data, so MS provides a 1TB SSD, which means extra storage space.

2. Sony has a lot of exclusives that are immersive, expansive, single player open world story adventures. (God of War, Last of Us, Until Dawn, Horizon Zero Dawn, etc... come to mind here) -- These games do not really need 4K 120FPS -- 4K 60 is "enough" for most of these incredibly immersive single player experiences, since they're not competitive multiplayer titles that have to contend with PC Cross-Play. But they do need consistently fast memory, and a much faster SSD to eliminate loading screens. So, Sony saved money by going with a smaller GPU (36 CU's instead of 56CUs) -- but smaller chips put out less heat, so they can be clocked higher. While Microsoft has 55% more CU's than Sony on their GPU, The Sony GPU is only 16% slower (PS5 pushes 10.3 Tflops vs the Series X GPU pushing 12 Tflops). Here, the TFlop numbers can be meaningfully compared because you have identical GPU architectures (both are RDNA 2 GPUs). With the money Sony saved by going with a smaller GPU, Sony can provide developers with 16GB of ram that's relatively fast - @448 GB/s. The Ram being slow than Microsoft's "fast" memory (@560GB/s) doesn't matter, because it's feeding a much smaller GPU, so Sony doesn't have to pipe in as much data to keep all the CU's properly fed with bits. On the SSD Side, when you're loading huge immersive worlds, it really matters that your SSD and custom controller are able to keep the chips fed properly, loading tons of assets like the mountains and trees and buildings in the distance... This is why Sony spent money on a much faster SSD. Sony's SSD is smaller -- at 825GB instead of 1TB, but the Speed is nearly 2x that of the Series X. (5.5GB/s raw disk speed). This will help the PS5 load in massive worlds far more efficiently. Finally, Sony put a lot of money into developing a custom Audio Engine that unlocks truly immersive directional audio, and far more advanced haptics on their controllers. Touch and Sound just brings in more of your senses to help immerse you in an experience.

At the end of the day, It's not about which console is faster and why that's "better". Both Microsoft and Sony made different choices BASED ON THE TYPES OF GAMES THEY HAVE ON THE PLATFORM, because they want you to have the best experience playing those games.

snippet.textDisplay: Saying a 12TF GPU is faster than a 10TF GPU is like saying a 300MHz CPU is faster than a 200MHz CPU. There are more variables to performance than just how many things it can do in a second, and the Megahertz Myth illustrates fairly clearly how the aforementioned 200MHz CPU could actually be more powerful than the 300MHz one because of things like more efficient instruction pipelining. I think you are falling into a similar trap with Teraflops. The Xbox may run faster, but does that mean it's more powerful or efficient? Only time will tell.
snippet.textOriginal: Saying a 12TF GPU is faster than a 10TF GPU is like saying a 300MHz CPU is faster than a 200MHz CPU. There are more variables to performance than just how many things it can do in a second, and the Megahertz Myth illustrates fairly clearly how the aforementioned 200MHz CPU could actually be more powerful than the 300MHz one because of things like more efficient instruction pipelining. I think you are falling into a similar trap with Teraflops. The Xbox may run _faster,_ but does that mean it's more _powerful_ or _efficient?_ Only time will tell.
